original_title: Japan, FAO gives US$4.6mn free fertilizer for Sri Lanka paddy farmers
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Japan has agreed to provide 4.6 million US dollars to boost paddy production in the dry and intermediate zones of Sri Lanka, a statement from The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) said.

The Government of Japan through the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) is providing 4.62 million dollars to 250,000 smallholder paddy farmers in the Dry and Intermediate Zones of Sri Lanka.
The farmers who hold up to one hectare of land will get 50 kilos of urea fertilizer each for the upcoming Yala cropping season free of charge, the statement said.
Ministry of Agriculture and the Department of Agrarian Development, will distribute the fertilizer.
The project will also provide smallholder paddy farmers information on the efficient use of fertilizer to maximize production.

During the 2022 Yala season, Sri Lanka had produced 1,461.675 metric tonnes of paddy, the lowest since 2018. Sri Lanka banned chemical fertilizer use in 2021 driving agriculture into a crisis. The ban was lifted in November 2021.
In the just concluded Maha season, paddy production was estimated  at 2.65 million metric tonnes. (Colombo/May17/2023)
